message: i have the o'reilly book. anywhere else i should start?

Pick a small program you've already written, and try re-implementing the core idea. I've got a couple basic ones that I tend to run through when working to learn new languages (Scala, Erlang, Go..) that run through some basics of IO, string manipulation, and concurrency.
That said, I find myself almost completely forgetting every bit of Scala I've learned each time I come back to it.
Like any language, I suppose. Same thing happened to me with Powershell that I was teached 2 weeks ago and tried to write myself for the first time yesterday.

Check out the source to a couple of interesting Scala projects on GitHub. Pick a project that does something of interest to you, but not a big framework like Lift that will be hard to orient yourself with.
Anecdotally I've been able to sneak Scala into some "Java Only!!1" codebases thanks to ScalaCheck: http://code.google.com/p/scalacheck/
…and it's a pretty great way to keep your Scala knowledge fresh while also removing the tedium of traditional Java unit testing.
Coming from a Rails background I am really enjoying the language, started with the Scala for the impatient rough cut PDF
